resources.string: The terminology section of this app will allow the user to enter the name of a term and to view the defination. The websites section shows the user 12 websites, that are useful for developing android apps.
The Terminology section contains definations from Labs 1 and 2. The websites section contains a list of 12 websites relating android programming.
The websites section of this app shows you with 12 options that are links to pages that will help you develop apps for android.

string-array.name: def
string-array.item: - adb allows us to connect/interact or go in to our AVD. Commands such as "adb shell"
- Using the emulator command, we can run the AVD through command line.
- We used android list avd to list our android virtual devices.
- This allows us to take screenshot inside the emulator. This way we can take screenshots of whats happening inside the emulator rather than, print screen and then cropping our image.
- Gradle is the build tool, it allows us to build our project.
- pm command with uninstall alllows us to remove the app.
- This is where all the errors and warnings are stored/written
- By using tree command, it looks like main is where all the files and folders go, in a project. It\'s where you start placing files.
- This directory contains lint files, and APK\'s, like the one we ran in part C4.
- Contains the layout files. How you want the text, images or items in your programs to look on the emulator when they get displayed.

- You can declare string variables and store or assign them some words. We created a file called "strings.xml" and created a variable called "app_name" and gave it the value "Android Gradle" which got printed in our emulator when we ran our hello world/seneca app.
- A project is where your app is stored, each project contains one app, but multiple files. Project name is the same as your app name
- An area or a section which contains tools and options.
- Gives us a quick selection to tools. There are a selection of tools outside in the main window such as SDK manager, emulator menu, run and much more.
- the bar that appears at the top of your screen/device. Above the "Hello World" string.
- It is a panel that is displayed in the middle of your project with your vm, that shows your project and the changes you make to it as you go.
- Let\'s you use features such as taking a screenshot within your vm, system information and give you information about your project and files as you work on it, whether if something failed or not.
- Lists all the recent projects that you worked on.
- The .idea directory contains a set of configuration files.
- It\'s a feature that allows the user to speed up the process of coding by reducing syntax errors.
- Live Layout means you can view your work/code as you go in the preview pane.
- Create an empty Git repository or reinitialize an existing one.
- This allows you to record the changes to your local respository.
- This allows you to update the remote repository with the local changes.
- Add file contents to the index.
- Fetch from and integrate with another repository or a local branch.
- Clone a repository into a new directory.
